Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Development of a Multidimensional Nonlinear Spectrometer Spanning the Ultraviolet to the Infrared
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award from the Major Research Instrumentation Program and support from the Chemistry Research Instrumentation Program, Professor Jennifer Ogilvie from the University of Michigan and colleagues Stephen Forrest, Kevin Kubarych, Theodore Norris and Vanessa Sih will develop a multispectral multidimensional non-linear (MMDS) spectrometer to enable studies of dynamical processes in atomic, molecular, and material systems spanning femtoseconds to seconds, from the ultraviolet (UV) to the infrared (IR) regimes. This will allow insight into DNA photodamage and repair mechanisms and metalloenzyme function. The ability to mix and match infrared, visible and ultraviolet wavelengths will be a novel and potentially very powerful technique. The investigators will create modules that will serve for outreach activities to K-12 students. Importantly, participation of students and postdoctoral associates in this project will serve to educate a new generation of instrumentalists.

The award is aimed at enhancing research and education at all levels, especially in areas such as the study of complex condensed phase systems. The instrument will also be used to probe the dynamics of the building blocks of biological matter: amino and nucleic acids, to gain insight into DNA photodamage and repair mechanisms and metalloenzyme function and will provide a tool for studying the physics of nanostructures. It is also noted that the instrument would address key questions relevant to improving the efficiency of organic photovoltaic devices.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit: Multidimensional spectroscopy is the optical analog to nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR), probing dynamical processes with ultrafast time resolution. At optical frequencies the technical challenges of multidimensional spectroscopy have hindered its progress until recently, where advances in laser sources and pulse-shaping have removed many obstacles to its implementation. Multidimensional spectroscopy in the visible and IR regimes has already enabled respective advances in our understanding of photosynthesis and the structural rearrangements of liquid water. To make the leap to the next decade of leading-edge ultrafast spectroscopy, it is necessary to extend and combine multidimensional techniques and frequency ranges, which have been largely restricted to operating in the distinct visible or IR regimes. Complex condensed phase systems have optical transitions spanning the UV to the IR, and exhibit dynamics relevant to function on timescales of femtoseconds to seconds, and beyond. In this project we have developed a multispectral multidimensional spectrometer (MMDS) to enable the study of condensed phase dynamics over this vast spectral and temporal range, enabling new multidimensional spectroscopy techniques and applications to a wide range of subjects. To date these have included enabling insight into charge separation mechanisms in natural and artificial light-harvesting materials, and the mechanisms of molecular motor operation. In the largely unexplored UV regime, future experiments with the MMDS will enable the probing of the dynamics of the building blocks of biological matter: amino and nucleic acids, to gain insight into DNA photodamage and repair mechanisms and metalloenzyme function. It will provide a unique tool for studying the physics of nanostructures, facilitating their design and control for applications ranging from solid-state lighting to quantum information. Using multidimensional spectroscopies that span the UV-IR, MMDS will address key questions relevant to improving the efficiency of organic photovoltaic devices. Combining visible and IR pulses, the MMDS will enable surface-specific spectroscopies in both the IR and in the visible to investigate protein-membrane interactions, and promising new surfaces such as catalytic electrodes. 

 

Broader Impact:Multidimensional spectroscopy is an emerging field but the technical difficulties of its implementation have limited its use to a small number of labs worldwide, studying a restricted set of scientific problems. Significant progress has recently been made towards simplifying the experimental implementation through the use of pulse-shaping. These advances, and recent developments in broadband femtosecond pulse generation provide the opportunity to develop a truly unique easy-to-use instrument to enable multidimensional spectroscopy spanning the UV-IR, with unprecedented combination spectroscopies. A common facility employing these advanced techniques will significantly broaden the scope of research and the user-base for multidimensional spectroscopy methods. It will enhance a wide range of research programs at UM and neighboring institutions by enabling pioneering spectroscopic measurements unavailable in any single PI laboratories. The research to be performed with the MMDS has the potential to significantly impact several of the nation’s highest research priorities, including energy conversion and storage, efficient lighting and information. The MMDS will provide an excellent resource to enhance the research programs and education of graduate students at neighboring institutions. To broaden the user base and educate them about the principles of multidimensional spectroscopy we organized an intensive open-access workshop to explore the applications of multidimensional spectroscopy across disciplines and teach researchers about the modeling and interpretation of multidimensional spectroscopy data. We also hosted numerous graduate students from laboratories across the US wishing to implement pulse-shaping-based multidimensional spectroscopy methods.
